articles.headline: As Spain’s Economy Falters, Bank Robberies Rise
articles.snippet: Robberies in 2009 are running 20 percent ahead of 2007’s pace in the nation with Europe’s highest jobless rate.
articles.abstract: Robberies in 2009 are running 20 percent ahead of 2007’s pace in the nation with Europe’s highest jobless rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain  The 52-year-old contractor was desperate to save his business. Unable to pay his workers and facing bankruptcy, Ausencio C. G., as Spanish police identify him, went to the bank  but not for a loan.

articles.headline: Hard-Line Force Extends Grip Over a Splintered Iran
articles.snippet: As Iran’s leaders splinter over the election crisis, the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps is working to crush the opposition.
articles.abstract: As Iran’s leaders splinter over the election crisis, the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps is working to crush the opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  As Iran’s political elite and clerical establishment splinter over the election crisis, the nation’s most powerful economic, social and political institution  the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps  has emerged as a driving force behind efforts to crush a still-defiant opposition movement.

articles.headline: Barnes & Noble Plans an Extensive E-Bookstore
articles.snippet: The retailer said users will have access to up to a million titles within the next year.
articles.abstract: The retailer said users will have access to up to a million titles within the next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four months after acquiring an e-book retailer, Barnes & Noble, the world’s largest chain of bookstores, is starting its own mega e-bookstore on its Web site, BN.com.

articles.headline: Obama’s Strategy to Reverse Manufacturing’s Fall
articles.snippet: Policy makers are looking for a way to revive manufacturing, a pillar of a powerful economy.
articles.abstract: Policy makers are looking for a way to revive manufacturing, a pillar of a powerful economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the Obama administration has a strategy for reviving manufacturing, Douglas Bartlett would like to know what it is.

articles.headline: U.S. Withheld Data on Risks of Distracted Driving
articles.snippet: In 2003, researchers at a federal agency proposed a long-term study of 10,000 drivers to assess the safety risk posed by cellphone use behind the wheel.
articles.abstract: In 2003, researchers at a federal agency proposed a long-term study of 10,000 drivers to assess the safety risk posed by cellphone use behind the wheel.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, researchers at a federal agency proposed a long-term study of 10,000 drivers to assess the safety risk posed by cellphone use behind the wheel.

articles.headline: Big Estimate, Worth Little, on Bailout
articles.snippet: Just how much could the bailout of the financial system end up costing American taxpayers?
articles.abstract: Just how much could the bailout of the financial system end up costing American taxpayers?
articles.lead_paragraph: Just how much could the bailout of the financial system end up costing American taxpayers?

articles.headline: Home Burials Offer an Intimate Alternative
articles.snippet: In the downturn, the do-it-yourself ethos extends to families burying loved ones, sometimes in their yards.
articles.abstract: In the downturn, the do-it-yourself ethos extends to families burying loved ones, sometimes in their yards.
articles.lead_paragraph: PETERBOROUGH, N.H.  When Nathaniel Roe, 92, died at his 18th-century farmhouse here the morning of June 6, his family did not call a funeral home to handle the arrangements.

articles.headline: Fed Aims to Hold Down Interest Rates
articles.snippet: Despite positive signs, Ben S. Bernanke said the labor market was weak and interest rates would likely stay low.
articles.abstract: Despite positive signs, Ben S. Bernanke said the labor market was weak and interest rates would likely stay low.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy is finally improving, but enough potholes lie ahead that the Federal Reserve needs to keep interest rates close to zero, at least until unemployment begins to come down, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told Congress on Tuesday.
